Docs.summary: Animates the value of a property between two target values using linear interpolation over a specified <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Timeline.Duration%2A>.

remarks.format:
## Remarks An animation updates the value of a property over a period of time. An animation effect can be subtle, such as moving a <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Shape> a few pixels left and right, or dramatic, such as enlarging an object to 200 times its original size while spinning it and changing its color. To create an animation in [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_winclient](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)], you associate an animation with an object's property value.
## Target Values The QuaternionAnimation class creates a transition between two target values. To set its target values, use its <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.From%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.To%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.By%2A> properties. The following table summarizes how the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.From%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.To%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.By%2A> properties may be used together or separately to determine an animation's target values.
|Properties specified|Resulting behavior| |--------------------------|------------------------| |<xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.From%2A>|The animation progresses from the value specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.From%2A> property to the base value of the property being animated or to a previous animation's output value, depending on how the previous animation is configured.| |<xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.From%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.To%2A>|The animation progresses from the value specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.From%2A> property to the value specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.To%2A> property.| |<xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.From%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.By%2A>|The animation progresses from the value specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.From%2A> property to the value specified by the sum of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.From%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.By%2A> properties.| |<xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.To%2A>|The animation progresses from the animated property's base value or a previous animation's output value to the value specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.To%2A> property.| |<xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.By%2A>|The animation progresses from the base value of the property being animated or a previous animation's output value to the sum of that value and the value specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.By%2A> property.|
> [!NOTE] > If you set both the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.To%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.By%2A> properties, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.To%2A> property takes precedence and the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimation.By%2A> property is ignored.
To use other interpolation methods or animate between more than two target values, use a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimationUsingKeyFrames> object.
For information about applying multiple animations to a single property, see [Key-Frame Animations Overview](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Freezable Features Because the QuaternionAnimation class inherits from <xref:System.Windows.Freezable>, QuaternionAnimation objects gain several special features, which include the following: they can be declared as , shared among multiple objects, made read-only to improve performance, cloned, and made thread-safe. For more information about the different features provided by <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> objects, see the [Freezable Objects Overview](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).

remarks.format: ## Remarks This constructor allows you to specify the quaternions that define the beginning and ending orientations of the model being animated, as well as the behavior of the animation's timeline when it is outside of its active period but its parent is inside its active or hold period.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the total amount by which the animation changes its starting value.
Docs.value: The total amount by which the animation changes its starting value. The default value is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use the By property when you want to animate a value "by" a certain amount, rather than specifying a starting or ending value. You may also use the By property with the property. The following table summarizes how the , , and By properties may be used together or separately to determine an animation's target values. |Properties specified|Resulting behavior| |--------------------------|------------------------| ||The animation progresses from the value specified by the property to the base value of the property being animated or to a previous animation's output value, depending on how the previous animation is configured.| | and |The animation progresses from the value specified by the property to the value specified by the property.| | and By|The animation progresses from the value specified by the property to the value specified by the sum of the and By properties.| ||The animation progresses from the animated property's base value or a previous animation's output value to the value specified by the property.| |By|The animation progresses from the base value of the property being animated or a previous animation's output value to the sum of that value and the value specified by the By property.| **Note** If you set both the and By properties, the property takes precedence and the By property is ignored. To use other interpolation methods or animate between more than two target values, use a object. ## XAML Attribute Usage <*object* `By`=""/> \- or - <*object* `By`="{[x:Null Markup Extension](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)}"/> ## XAML Property Element Usage \<*object*> <*object*.`By`> \< /> \ ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|

Docs.summary: Creates a modifiable clone of this , making deep copies of this object's values. When copying dependency properties, this method copies resource references and data bindings (but they might no longer resolve) but not animations or their current values.
Docs.returns: A modifiable clone of the current object. The cloned object's <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen%2A> property will be even if the source's <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen%2A> property was

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method is used to produce modifiable copies of frozen <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> objects (or any <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object). For convenience, this method shadows the inherited version with a strongly typed implementation.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.Clone%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Easing functions allow you to create a variety of specialized animation effects including bouncing, spring oscillations, and various magnitude acceleration and deceleration animations.

Docs.value: The starting value of the animation. The default value is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The following table summarizes how the From, , and properties may be used together or separately to determine an animation's target values. |Properties Specified|Resulting Behavior| |--------------------------|------------------------| |From|The animation progresses from the value specified by the From property to the base value of the property being animated or to a previous animation's output value, depending on how the previous animation is configured.| |From and |The animation progresses from the value specified by the From property to the value specified by the property.| |From and |The animation progresses from the value specified by the From property to the value specified by the sum of the From and properties.| ||The animation progresses from the animated property's base value or a previous animation's output value to the value specified by the property.| ||The animation progresses from the base value of the property being animated or a previous animation's output value to the sum of that value and the value specified by the property.| **Note** If you set both the and properties, the property takes precedence and the property is ignored. To use other interpolation methods or animate between more than two target values, use a object. ## XAML Attribute Usage <*object* `From`=""/> \- or - <*object* `From`="{[x:Null Markup Extension](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)}"/> ## XAML Property Element Usage \<*object*> <*object*.`From`> \< /> \ ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|

MemberSignature.Value: protected override System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Quaternion GetCurrentValueCore (System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Quaternion defaultOriginValue, System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Quaternion defaultDestinationValue, System.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationClock animationClock);

.method familyhidebysig virtual instance valuetype System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Quaternion GetCurrentValueCore(valuetype System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Quaternion defaultOriginValue, valuetype System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Quaternion defaultDestinationValue, class System.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationClock animationClock) cil managed

Docs.param: The suggested origin value, used if the animation does not have its own explicitly set start value.
The suggested destination value, used if the animation does not have its own explicitly set end value.
An that generates the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Clock.CurrentTime%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Clock.CurrentProgress%2A> used by the animation.
Docs.summary: Calculates a value that represents the current value of the property being animated, as determined by the .
Docs.returns: The calculated value of the property, as determined by the current animation.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the `defaultOriginValue` is the first in the composition chain, this value will be the snapshot value (if one is available) or the base property value; otherwise this value will be the value returned by the previous animation in the chain with an <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationClock> that is not <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Clock.Stopped%2A>.
The `defaultDestinationValue` is the base value if the animation is in the first composition layer of animations on a property; otherwise the value is the output value from the previous composition layer of animations for the property.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the target property's current value should be added to this animation's starting value.
Docs.value: if the target property's current value should be added to this animation's starting value; otherwise, . The default value is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the animation has only one of its , , or properties set, setting this property has no effect. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None| > [!NOTE] > This dependency property is unusual in that the identifier field for it comes from , and is shared by various derived classes.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies whether the animation's value accumulates when it repeats.
Docs.value: if the animation accumulates its values when its <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Timeline.RepeatBehavior%2A> property causes it to repeat its simple duration. otherwise, . The default value is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks When this property is set to `true`, the animation's output values only accumulate when the animation's property causes it to repeat its simple duration. It does not accumulate its values when it restarts because its parent repeated or because its clock was restarted from a call. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None| > [!NOTE] > This dependency property is unusual in that the identifier field for it comes from , and is shared by various derived classes.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the animation's ending value.
Docs.value: The ending value of the animation. The default value is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The following table summarizes how the , To, and properties may be used together or separately to determine an animation's target values. |Properties Specified|Resulting Behavior| |--------------------------|------------------------| ||The animation progresses from the value specified by the property to the base value of the property being animated or to a previous animation's output value, depending on how the previous animation is configured.| | and To|The animation progresses from the value specified by the property to the value specified by the To property.| | and |The animation progresses from the value specified by the property to the value specified by the sum of the and properties.| |To|The animation progresses from the animated property's base value or a previous animation's output value to the value specified by the To property.| ||The animation progresses from the base value of the property being animated or a previous animation's output value to the sum of that value and the value specified by the property.| **Note** If you set both the To and properties, the To property takes precedence and the property is ignored. To use other interpolation methods or animate between more than two target values, use a object. ## XAML Attribute Usage <*object* `To`=""/> \- or - <*object* `To`="{[x:Null Markup Extension](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)}"/> ## XAML Property Element Usage \<*object*> <*object*.`To`> \< /> \ ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|
